150557365.review:
This game has become my genuine favourite of all time. The media surrounding it and the content itself is just phenomenal, with an amazing and gripping story to it. The simplicity of the art-style is eye candy, and the contrast of the psychological horror elements to it is just masterfully done. The RPG section of the game is lacking a bit in my opinion, basically being just rock-paper-scissors but I've had loads of fun with it nonetheless. Exploring Headspace is a treat within itself, looking through every nook and cranny for a new item, interaction or secret. The characters feel like real people with real human emotion. I have genuinely no complaints with this game and I can proudly say that it influenced me a lot.
Eitherway, I seem to have came across this "Marian" character in the game. After watching playthroughs and tutorials, I can't seem to find anymore footage of him. Nor can I find any information on him online. Anyone else in the same scenario?

This game kinda sucks. It was unclear what I was getting into but the trailers made it look interesting enough. Unfortunately it's tagged with "psychological horror" when it probably aligns more with Adventure Time or Steven Universe. It's a fluffy cotton candy game about mental illness, it is not psychological horror.

If there's some depth that I am missing by giving up at the 3 hour mark I'd still say it's the fault of the game. I did not feel like the world was interesting enough for me to want to explore.

I will give it up that this is probably the most polished RPG Maker game I've ever played, but beyond that I can't in good faith recommend this.

150388750.review: Let me just say without any spoilers that this game is a such masterpiece of gameplay, storytelling, plot, emotion, music, graphics, art styles, and dialogue from beginning to end. It's such a great balance of being dark, horror, being light-hearted, colorful, and fun. I am very glad I went in blindly playing the game otherwise it would've ruined it for me and blind made the experience all the worthwhile. Despite the fact I hardly ever play horror games, the gameplay is very unique and emotion based. Undertale did not make me cry although I love Undertale and Deltarune this game however made me bawl my eyes out like a fucking baby and made me feel things I did not want to feel. What's also great about this game is just like Undertale the choices you make throughout a specific route really affect the consequences. It really makes you feel for these characters and makes you care about them. I know Omori may not be a game for everyone but I was recommended by one of my best friends to play it and my boyfriend bought the game for me and I bought it for him lol. I highly recommend playing OMORI but blindly! It is one of the best video games I have ever played! Definitely considering doing the Hikikomori route and OMORI route next!

150263146.review:
One of those games that stay in your memories for many years after completing them. 
The characters are very well written: dialogues are creative and filled with puns, jokes and funny interactions between them. 
The story is engaging and interesting: plot twists and secrets won't be missing.
The art style is very unique, as in being a mix of various genres that work great together. 
The gameplay is fine - it's a RPG adventure with horror elements to it. Personally I find it to be its weakest point, but I was so absorbed into the story that I didn't care too much for the lack of depth of the combat system. 
Overall a great game, possibly even a must play, even tho it could be a bit too niche to reach that status. But personally I would highly recommend it.

150259260.review:
it's been years since i last wrote a review of a game that was more than a sentence or two.

but here goes:

omori is a turn based rpg set in and outside of a teenager's dream.

its fantastical and fun elements of the dream parallel and contrast the real life sections of the game, making for something serious with a lot of heart.

this game is like a rollercoaster, but it truly is a perfect blend of humor and sadness.

also, the energy mechanic during battles is such a neat idea that im gonna be sad to play other turn based rpgs that dont have it.

don't let anyone tell u otherwise.

and [i] don't ever let anyone tell u that it's too late to tell the truth. [/i]

it never is.

please purchase this video game so there can be more like it.

this game goes right there, next to mother 3. <3

play the game.

I won't be forgetting this one anytime soon, if ever. 
11/10.

A deeply emotional experience that warrants multiple playthroughs, "Omori" is one of the greatest indie RPGs to grace my steam library. [h1]Please, if you have not yet, play OMORI[/h1]

Please, if you haven't played OMORI already, do so now. I really wish that I could play this again for the first time, I can't say that for any other game I have ever played. To say the least, it was a life changing experience. 

There's not much I can say without spoiling the entire plot, it is vital that you go into this without any prior knowledge to the story, this is also why I advise against searching information about this up until after you've played it, or at least be very careful in doing so.
With all of the setbacks leading up to the release of OMORI, you can really see how that time went into perfecting it, it was definitely the best decision that the developers could've made in not rushing their time creating this masterpiece. 
Every single character in this game is appealing and has it's own charm, this applies to the areas you can find too, they're all very unique and loveable to say the least about them.

The final thing I would like to comment on is the OST, in my opinion it would beat out undertale, or any other very acclaimed soundtracks for that matter. I don't think there is a singular bad song or unfitting background track to any area in this entire game, with the context it just makes it all better too.

Please. Play OMORI.

149772280.review:
OMORI: Lidiar con lo inolvidable.
Hace un par de semanas acabé el juego OMORI, es un simple RPG que trata sobre cómo un chaval lidia con un evento traumático que sucedió hace 4 años así como sus consecuencias y cómo influye en su día a día. Este chico se llama Sunny.

En este juego divagamos entre dos mundos: el 	headspace (nuestros sueños) y el mundo real, concretamente en la ciudad de FARAWAY. En este mundo ficticio todo parece ser perfecto: estás rodeado de tus amigos de toda la vida, te diviertes, recreas momentos que han sido inolvidables, todos te quieren y básicamente puedes hacer todo lo que quieras. Eres el "Dios" de ese mundo, el soñador. Aquí eres OMORI, un alter ego que representa al personaje principal del juego (Sunny) en este maravilloso mundo. 

OMORI no está solo. Sus amigos Kel, Aubrey, Hero, Basil y su hermana Mari siempre están ahí y lo conocen a la perfección. A OMORI no le gusta estar solo, le da miedo el auga, las alturas, las arañas y... otras cosas correspondientes con los miedos reales de Sunny. Aclarar también que estos amigos "imaginarios" representan a los amigos reales del protagonista, aunque como se verá en el juego, no todos vuelven a ser lo mismos tras la ocurrencia de un evento que los marcará durante toda su vida. Pero bueno, pase lo que pase, en el mundo de los sueños eres feliz ya que puedes modificarlo a tu gusto y borrar aquello que no te agrade... ¿pero será suficiente?

Kel es un chiquillo muy energético y risueño, siempre está feliz y le gustar chinchar mucho a Aubrey, una chica muy agradable y alegre que siempre anima a los demás y también se queja cuando encuentra alguna injusticia o algo que no es correcto. A lo largo del tiempo se verá como Aubrey cambia, no siendo la persona que era, y descubrirás la triste realidad de la verdad. Nadie sabe si Kel está mal, ya que lo oculta muy bien. De hecho, será tu primera compañía después de 4 años en la vida real.

Hero es mucho más tranquilo que su hermano Kel y es mayor, junto a Mari, que el resto del grupo. Podríamos decir que representa la figura de Padre dentro de él y siempre está al cuidado de los pequeños. Además es muy educado y considerado, usa un lenguaje cortés y puede convencer a cualquiera con su picaresca sonrisa. Quiere mucho a Mari y pasa rato junto a ella cuando puede, la cual toma la figura de Madre organizando sus picnics y velando por la seguridad de todos y, sobre todo, de su hermano. 

Basil es el mejor amigo de OMORI. Es un chico tímido apasionado por la botánica, no suele hablar de su vida ni contar sus inquietudes con todo el mundo y le gusta fotografiar a sus amigos en momentos esporádicos, para conservar la naturalidad del momento y la belleza pura de cada persona. Solo suele hablar con OMORI de estas cosas ya que según él es un "buen escuchador" y se siente seguro contándole todo ello. Siempre que pasa algún problema confía en que todo se solucionará y que estarán (él y sus amigos) bien, creyéndo que no hay ningún problema... aunque esto no servirá esta vez.

A lo largo del juego podrás explorar como cada uno de estos personajes ha vivido cómo afrontar las consecuencias del evento que los marcó de por vida. Sobre todo desde el punto de vista de Sunny, destrozado por dentro, el cual no ha superado todavía los sucesos ocurridos y tendrá que zanjar varios asuntos pendientes antes de que se le acabe el tiempo, ya que tiene que mudarse en cuatro días de su ciudad natal. El juego aprovecha muy bien una herramienta que todos usamos a menudo: el recuerdo y el olvido, algo que es tan obvio que existe pero que a la misma vez aterrador desde cómo se nos presenta en la historia.

No recomiendo jugar este juego si no tienes la suficiente madurez para identificar que al final es una historia de ficción y, sobre todo, entender las sensaciones y sentimientos que se tratan en él. Yo he llorado, me he frustado, me he visto proyectado en el juego y me he incluso bloqueado en su final a la misma vez que me he alegrado cuando estaba en el mundo idílico de Sunny y viviendo tal y como a él le gustaría. La banda sonora es brutal, ya veréis. Si ascaso, el juego puede ser un poco largo, pero no requiere visitar todas las zonas ni realizar ninguna misión alternativa para conseguir avanzar en la historia principal.

149688424.review:
OMORI is a psychological horror game, a game which I jumped into when I wasn't really in the best place in life, a friend recommended me and even paid for my copy of the game, It tackles dark topics which include depression, anxiety, and suicide, It's really important to take these warnings seriously and look out for yourself before jumping head first into a game with trigger warnings like these, don't be me (I broke-down way too often)

 I would highly recommend playing the game yourself first. especially blind, onto the review now.

My first play-through was a quiet night. Being completely alone and isolated helped me understand this game correctly. The first few hours were something I've never experienced in a game before, little things like the title screen, the music, and the recurring themes of familiarity of this dream world through its fantastic soundtrack, The music seriously enriches the player's understanding of this overall plot-rich/traumatic experience.

OMORI’s gameplay is in the form of a turn-based RPG, with a lot of exploration on the side, really simple and easy to understand, and can also be very rewarding in a very satisfying way, A lot of what you do in this game is explore with your friends and relive old memories together, while also making new ones which I found to enjoy a lot personally. especially with its story that heavily revolves around its lovable cast of characters, They all have their unique personalities, and their own lives which isn't dived into too much, but a lot of it is hinted at in a way that's realistic during the story.

the only criticism I would have for this masterpiece is its pacing, There are quite a few areas that drag on a bit too long for my liking especially when trying to interact with everything in the game. I find this game to be very hard to be able to replay with that in mind, especially for the many different endings it has to offer.

I really enjoyed OMORI and its wonderful art style, It's a game I will remember for years to come, It's had such a massive impact on me as a person through the story and tells a really important message that I think I needed to hear during the release of the game when I played it, which it delivers greatly on. definitely will be a steamroller of emotions and bangers once you launch this game. Thanks for reading my review.

149597493.review:
Though OMORI is overall an enjoyable experience, the game is bloated by ~15 hours of gameplay that is generally unimportant to the main story of the game, save for the bits and pieces of the final Headspace sections and the very beginning of the game. The excessively large amount of dungeons bloats the game (especially in the final dungeon) and overall dampens the otherwise enjoyable story the game carries. The game feels as though it was not confident enough in its story to simply allow it to progress naturally without massive multi-hour sections of minor, one-note character moments, relatively boring rock-paper-scissors gameplay that tows the line of being mildly fun, so easy its boring, or so damage-spongy it's unbearable (looking at you, Humphrey), and slog-filled dungeons that only serve to meet Kickstarter goals and distract from the gripping story of the Real World sections of the game. Though this is likely intentional, showing how Sunny uses his Headspace as an escape from the stresses of the Real World and the trauma he has experienced, it does not translate well into the pacing of the game and after Pyrefly Forest, I was just wishing I could get back to the story and learn more about the real characters, not their watered-down, idealized Headspace counterparts.

I suppose this is all to say that the story of the Real World was so enjoyable and intriguing that the game left me actively wishing for more. Unfortunately, it only takes up around 5 hours of gameplay. Kel, Aubrey, Hero, and Basil are enjoyable characters and feel almost real, making their plights more interesting and making you feel for their characters. Watching the characters process and attempt to grow from their past is enjoyable and the overall message of moving forward from past actions and trauma is one that should be seen more in media and I am glad this game went to the effort to flesh out its messaging.

I'd recommend watching a let's play over playing the game yourself, since that way you can trim the fat of the game if you want to avoid the overly long Headspace sections. There's one section towards the very end I'd say is worth playing, but it's so late in the game I can't justify telling someone to spend $20 just to experience a 30 minute to 1 hour long section when you could get the same experience as it from Yume Nikki or its various fan sequels or clones for free with the added bonus of a better atmosphere.

149583552.review:
This game was SO close to being a masterpiece.

I usually start with the things that are good about the game but i am doing the opposite with Omori.
I know this point will be kind of subjective to some people but I value replayability a lot in games, I like going back to games I played to replay them, but I do not feel that way with Omori.
There are just some things from this game that affect this factor, which I will list right now:
1. The pacing was way too slow.
I don't mind when games are supposed to be slow and omori is a game that takes time to complete, but this one felt a bit too much.
That kind of hurts some moments of the game where sometimes i felt kind of bored and wanted something to happen, and this is not a game where I wanted to get bored at times, rather intrigued due to the story.
2. The game was a bit too easy.
Now, don't get me wrong, I get why this game was super hard, and hey, I am not saying games being easy makes the game overall worse, but I have to admit that it can hurt when replaying. At least for me.
3. Game was a bit too long.
I am not including extra content or other things to do here.
Sometimes it dragged way too long about things or certain sections just took an unnecessary amount of time to move on to another thing.
Again, I get why it's this way, but there was sometimes too much dialog, or some events could have been faster, yada yada.

These 3 things also can hurt the gameplay a bit, and gameplay is quite important for a game.
I also do not feel like the RPG part was something special, it's not bad tho, it works very well specially with the emotion system, but it's not amazing.
I would have liked if the side-quests also gave you "better rewards". Because sometimes they take the longest to complete, and is return sometimes they give you some clams that you could have gotten elsewhere or in a faster way. I am not saying I don't like them, they are a cool addition and a little extra, but they don't feel rewarding.

Gameplay and replayability is something I really care about, but that's pretty much the things I have against this game.
The rest of the game tho? It's amazing!

The story is perfect and original, there aren't a lot of games that speak about topics like phobia or depression in the way that Omori does, it's pretty unique in that department.
The characters are also perfect, there is absolutely nothing wrong with them, they are charmy, they are iconic and their designs are really cool.
The music is also insane! I see nobody talking about Omori's soundtrack but it fits both the RPG part and the topic that is covering, music is super important too and honestly, I wouldn't change a single track.
The style of the game is also really well done, mixing pixel-art with some realistic images and some anime-style drawings and characters was executed surprisingly well, specially for an RPG.
There is also quite a lot of stuff to do in this game, between side-quests, or secrets, or leveling up your party members, or getting some achievements. RPGs have a common flaw that is not having anything aside from the main story, so Omori doing this is a blast and I can see why 100% completing this game can be quite fun.

Overall, this was an incredible game and a great experience, specially the experience part that I would recommend.
It does suck that the bad things about it are kinda big for me, but if you do not mind them, you will think this game is amazing, and it is.
And for those saying this game is mid, no it's not mid.

RECOMMENDED!
8.8/10

149484131.review:
I made it through the good ending but I wasn't impressed and I don't see myself playing the other routes.

The writing in this game is not convincing or engaging. Many features of the story felt very unbelievable (I don't mean the fantasy aspects, obviously). The characters don't act their ages and they don't have convincing reactions to the events they've gone through. They talk like characters in a children's cartoon, which is jarring for a game that deals with themes like suicide, mental illness and [spoiler]murder[/spoiler]. The different pieces of the game also didn't seem to add up to anything -- the whole thing felt like a collection of disparate elements that had nothing to do with each other. For how much story you actually get, there was a disproportionate amount of silly filler that wasn't entertaining (a lot of lame, forced humor) and didn't connect in any way to the real plot. All the side quests/plots are tedious and unrewarding.

I kept going because of the driving mystery (eventually skipping everything but the main plot actions), but in the end, the final reveal [spoiler]that Sunny killed his sister and he and Basil framed it as a suicide[/spoiler] made even less sense than the rest of the game. [spoiler]Why would Sunny, who never had any violent tendencies, suddenly do something like that? How and why did two twelve year olds come up with such a morbid deception? If it really was just an accident, why did they feel the need to present it as a suicide? How did anyone not notice that Mari's death was caused by blunt force trauma, not hanging? How did Basil manage to keep this a secret for four years?[/spoiler] The [i]reason[/i] for these events is largely left up to implication and only explained in some game data. [spoiler]But even given the explanation that Mari was putting too much pressure on Sunny before the recital, it was never shown that Mari's perfectionism had led to harsh treatment of anyone else.[/spoiler] 

It also feels like a major piece of the payoff is missing, since [spoiler]you don't get to see Aubrey, Kel and Hero's reactions to Sunny's revelation[/spoiler]. It's implied that [spoiler]they simply forgive him[/spoiler], which also rings hollow -- [spoiler]as sensitive, traumatized teenagers who have just been through serious emotional turmoil, it's likely that it would not be easy at all for them to adjust to this new understanding of events, even if they choose not to blame Sunny[/spoiler].

I'd been looking for a game to fill the Deltarune-shaped hole in my heart, but sadly, this was not it.

149353261.review:
The game came off as pretentious to me when I initially tried playing it. I came back with a friend after a few months and we both thought it had a lot of great style, but leaned too far into absurdism (one of the supposed jokes in the beginning was about a nose talking to a leaf about a bunny...no punchline or context to pull it together, just random words together in a sentence), visuals for the sake of visuals, uneven pacing and definitely tonally uneven. The gameplay also seemed disjointed. There are no horror elements in the beginning. Instead, after 30 minutes of slice of life, absurdist, fluffy walking and reading text, the game then introduces battles. After 10 minutes the gameplay then shifts to that of an RPG Maker horror game, complete with a very telegraphed jump shock. I was having a very hard time holding interest both times I played, and by the time the turn based battles and horror aspects were introduced, I had a hard time being invested.

I did think the game had great style, especially with all of the hand drawn elements. I didn't think it all fit with the pixel style of the graphics however. I also thought there was some inventiveness in the combat with the different statuses, the positive and negative buffs in each, and how the statuses form a rock paper scissors weakness system. I also enjoyed all the tracks I heard.

This game has an overwhelming positive score and quite frankly I am very surprised. However it seems some thematic elements such as depression and suicide, as well as the art really resonated with most people who played it. It's possible that this game is just not for me, and that is fine, but I can't really recommend it to anyone.

It's thoughtful, well made, visually gorgeous... but the ending [spoiler] felt like it was made that way for no real purpose other than to be edgy edgelords. It ruined my outlook on the game quite significantly as it sort of shit all over the character development that happens throughout the game [/spoiler].

It took me about 23hrs to clear with a few side quests completed, so I feel the pricing on it is fair and tbh this is my sweet spot for game length. I didn't feel like it dragged on at all, and it was long enough to explore things nicely. The music is a 10/10, art is 10/10, gameplay is a solid 8/10 and I'll recommend the game, but I have conflicted feelings about just how genuinely my recommendation is given how cheated I felt by it.

Please be aware of the content warnings for this game. They're not to be taken lightly. There's more comprehensive lists than the game advises and you can see some of them at https://www.dualshockers.com/omori-controversy-explained/ .

If you are in crisis and need to talk to someone, there are a few different global orgs listed at https://www.helpguide.org/find-help.htm

[hr][/hr]
Ya hace un tiempo que jugué este juego, y no había pensado en hacerle una reseña hasta ahora que volví a ver el final del juego por Youtube y pensé en que, por como amo este juego, debía hacerle una reseña.

Voy a evitar cualquier tipo de spoiler porque este juego se disfruta más si entrás al desnudo. Creo que es el único juego que me puede hacer [b]llorar[/b] cada vez que veo su final, me resulta extremadamente emotivo, es un juego audiovisualmente hermoso y aún mejor si a  historia se refiere. Los personajes son prácticamente todos muy entrañables, amo a los protagonistas su dinámica entre sí [strike](doy mi vida por Hero)[/strike].

Cuando toqué por primera vez este juego no le dí la oportunidad que se merecía, pensé era distinto a lo que me imaginaba por lo que terminé abandonándolo sin haber avanzado mucho, tiempo después le dí otra oportunidad y [b]DIOS[/b] me arrepiento de no haberle dado su tiempo.

Esta reseña es totalmente subjetiva, me baso únicamente en lo que sentí durante mi experiencia jugandolo y después de terminarlo, pero por favor, si tienen el tiempo, [b]háganse el favor de jugarlo[/b], es fácilmente uno de mis juegos favoritos.

[b]ACLARACIÓN: El juego no está traducido al español pero existen mods para traducirlo hechos por fans[/b]

This is the best game I've finished so far in 2023.

I used the CEP mod (Community Enhancement Pack) for an expanded number of save slots and quality of life fixes from the community. I'd recommend it -- made playing through a better experience. One minor nit: there is no steam cloud save support, so you have to manually transfer your saves between Steam Deck and PC if you play that way.

148956520.review:
Omori se presenta a ti como el típico RPG de trama enigmática y atmósfera cómica, pero mientras más avanzas en el juego, vas descubriendo que es mucho más que eso. En primer lugar, el combate era normalito, te presentaban una mecánica de emociones que puedes usar para cambiar tus stats o los del enemigo, pero no se sentía como algo pensado con profundidad, sino más bien algo que añadieron para ser diferentes. Otros aspectos destacables son el apartado la música y el apartado visual que va variando entre pixelart y un estilo que parece dibujado con crayola. Junto con el soundtrack logran establecer bastante bien la atmosfera y darle atractivo al juego. Pero también debemos tener en cuenta que este es un juego de terror, lo cual observamos sobre todo en la impecable forma en la que se te presentan las pistas para que empieces a intentar descifrar lo que realmente está pasando, sobretodo casi al final, en la secuencia llamada “The Truth”, una de las más impactantes que he presenciado en un videojuego con un plot twist que me dejó atónito.
Bueno, no quiero entrar en detalles para evitar spoilearlos, pero puedo decir que mientras progresaba en la historia, pensaba en lo increíble que me parecía cómo podían generar tantas emociones en mí, ya sea alegría, incomodidad, frustración, sorpresa, etc.

Bought this game based on the 55k positive reviews. For the first 2/3rds of the game I would agree. Music, art direction, gameplay, dialogue, and story are all amazing. Here I need to break my gripes into 2 sections, story and game gripes. For those avoiding spoilers, ill save you the time and say I got this at like a 5/10 for me personally. The final 3rd of the game just really ruined it for me. Wouldnt recommend it to anyone I personally know, but if you want a Horror JRPG with some badass music and dope combat give it a shot.

Gameplay: *Possible Spoils* The gameplay loop is Dream World (Bulk of the gameplay) into the Real World (Bulk of the Story). When I got to the 3rd Dream World section, the pacing really fell off for me personally. Its the longest of the DW segments and the back to back bosses was unnecessary. Everything else was fine and unique. 

STORY: *ABSOLUTELY SPOILERS DO NOT READ* 
.
.
.
.
.
.
,
,
Ok so I know this will get hated, but what was that ending? Regardless of what Sunny did being on purpose or accident, why am I to feel bad for him. It really feels like the game wants me to justify his redemption due to all the "trauma" hes been dealing with. But what about the pain and suffering he inflicted upon basil? Not only did he put basil through the "accident", he hung his "best friend' out to dry. What about the pain he caused to all of his friends? WHAT ABOUT THE FUCKING CAT? Most killers start off by killing helpless animals. Also makes sense because what is the most common enemy in SUNNY'S Dream...........bunnies. Completing this game gave me a heavy SH2, except trying to get me to justify James is a good guy.

THIS COULD ALL JUST BE HOW I INTERPRETED THE STORY! I UNDERSTAND THERE ARE DEEPS DIVES EVERYWHERE! This is just my raw feelings after just completing the game.

148318057.review:
(Only have 1.2 hours because I first played on xbox gamepass before it was removed and I got gifted)



Omori, Omori, Omori. I have alot of things to say about this funny little game. [b]Spoiler warning, of course.[/b]

I first played this game at around october of last year, I've heard of Omori beforehand but I never had a chance to play it or even know the plot, story, or that it would be an RPG. but I knew I had to play it someday.
This is easily, my 3rd favorite game of all time, and it is hard to top that. So why is it in the top 3? well.

In Omori, you play as Omori (Shocking). which also means KILL in romanian. But you also play as Sunny, (Or Sar as I named him at the start.). You begin in a white void, a white space if you may. With nothing but a computer, sketchbook, tissue paper, your lovely cat MEWO, a knife that drops out of knowhere, a lightbulb that is pitch black, and a white door. entering such door brings you to a very fun and pretty world called WHITESPACE! a fun little place with many activies and people which are totally not designed by your alter ego to hide a horrifying truth! :D

Here lies your friends Kel, Aubrey, Hero, and Basil (I thought Basil was a girl at first, turns out he's gay in headcanon). aswell as your lovely big sister MARI. MARI is kind of like the mother of the friend groud and helping hand, which explains why she is always next to a save point with a basket of food that heals your team physically (But not emotionally...)

After getting to meet all the main chararcters and looking at Basils PHOTO ALBUM, you play Hide & Seek with them and some other people, Beat up a bully which had Basil captive, and go to Basils house around 300 feet away, learning more about the FIGHT system in this game, which consist of turn based combat with your friends and enemies, aswell as moods that affect your stats and an energy bar that fills up as your team takes damage which lets  you do team attacks and an ultimate attack once its filled.

Remember that PHOTO ALBUM? well, Basil decides to take a photo before entering the house, but due to Aubrey and Kel's  fighting to see the photo first, Basil falls over and all the photos fall on the ground, Basil and hero pick them up and then we arrange them back into place in his house.
But then, one more photo slips out, and Basil makes the fatal mistake of picking it up...

[i] "Huh? Whats this? Did I take this photo?" [/i]

[i] "Something about it seems... So familiar." [/i]

[i] "N-No... That can't be..." [/i]

[i] Dark roots begin forming at Basil's feet [/i]

[b] "MARI... She's..."- [/b]

The screen cuts to black. Flashing the photo for a single frame of video.

You cut back to whitespace, with no way of getting out, until you check your menu

-ESC
- [b] STAB [/b] EQUIP POCKET SKILLS OPTIONS
-STAB
- STAB WHO?
- OMORI

Omori pulls out a knife, with seemingly only a moment of hesitation. He stabs himself, killing him for the time being...

afterwards theres a monolouge between Sunny and Basil. about old pictures, and how it makes them feel now.

I wont spoil anything else, I just wanna say. Thank you OMOCAT. Thank you for making such a great game, From the bottom of my heart, Thank you Edith for buying me this game. And Screw you Microsoft, for taking this amazing game out of gamepass.

148309349.review:
This game means a lot to me, it's a game dealing about grief, escapism and forgiveness.

The many years of this game being in development was definitely worth the wait, you can tell how much love and effort went into the game. The art style, story, and concepts are all things I love about it. This game is such a comfort for me, the characters are well written and relatable, the different areas can be fun to explore, the different routes you can take can be fun to experience. I also love how the jump scares aren't just screaming in your face constantly, they're unsettling and the atmosphere can build that up. If you love psychological horror that is hidden by a colorful and friendly cover and RPG's then this game might be for you.

10/10, great game that is going to be sticking with me for awhile.

148304459.review:
I spent around half of my first run teetering on the edge not knowing if I would categorize the game as simply good, or great. But then enough awesome happened to settle my choice and go for a 100% clear.

Something I could feel and that was proven during replaying was the lack of QOL for certain things. Especially not being able to skip some bits that can drag, and the game structure that is quite punishing for some achievements if you didn't plan for it.

What I really loved on the other hand, and that were still fun on the third/fourth time, were the bosses. It all meshes really well, the emotions mechanic merging with the character of the bosses, their banger theme, and their moves. It wasn't just battles, but experiencing them.

During most of the story, I had a small fear that I would be disappointed by the resolution somehow, but when reaching it I was conquered.

The gameplay might be simple, but the battles are fun in their way of using a sort of stance dynamic through emotions. It's deeper than expected, although making it tend on the easy side but I don't mind that at all.

The art style is also something I really enjoy, something with childish substance made with skill. This game is quite clever with a good amount of fun and integrated references.

The game was endearing and the combat worked well for me, it was worth experiencing.
All I have to say in the end is WHEN I FLEX, I FEEEEEEL MY BEEEEEEEST!

I went through some super challenging times in the years before playing this game. I went to therapy, and learnt lots of useful stuff about myself and processed a load of emotions I had suppressed for a long time. This game deals with some heavy topics and really brought out some strong feelings about friendships and grief.
The first time I played this game was on game pass, and I sobbed the whole way through. I loved it so much that I had to buy it here and play through it again half a year later. This game is a piece of art. Its characters are super well written and loveable. The visuals are cryptic, vibrant, and calming, and the soundtrack is absolutely phenomenal. OMORI is my favourite game of all time, I'm sure you will love it.

Despite the balance issues though, this is a great online fps and I would recommend it to anyone else who loves this type of stuff.

I could not recommend this game more. 

The gameplay is simple, yet closely linked to the story and its themes. I think it is safe to say that its comparable to any turn based rpg (like Earthbound and Undertale)

The visual art when battling foes is quite stunning. It always looks like the main protagonist drew it with coloured pencils. 

The soundtrack is perfect and captures the situation it wants to paint to the player. I still listen to it in my day to day life. I plan to also buy it so I can keep it in my music collection. 

But most of all, the story is the strongest aspect of the game. For me, it achieved in trying to convey what the main character felt and it was highly emotional. Fear, despair, loneliness, grief and others. I was not a joy ride, but it was one that I am proud to have seen through the end...

147975182.review:
This might sound hilarious and pathetic but this game literally sent me to get a therapy appointment... Lately (for a couple of years) I have been neglecting my life engaging in too much escapism doing stuff like playing video games all day (including OMORI) to ignore my mental issues after/while going through *heavy* grief but this beautiful ending [i](the good one!)[/i] made me realize that, even though it's not easy at all and it requires a lot of strength, it's better to try to face your traumas head on rather than pretending they don't exist and everything is fine. Well, it's not like I was stupid enough to not realize that before, but it's hard to get out of that loop and ask for help. Yet OMORI managed to slap me so hard that I thought "okay that's it I'm getting help I can't keep going at it like Sunny" because I saw too much of my own behavior in the main character's story/decisions/relationships [i](hell, a couple of times I also haven't gotten out of my house for several months 💀)[/i]and it did NOT look good from an outsider perspective! that was quite uncomfortable for me!! [spoiler]I, too, accidentally damaged my friendships because I had fallen too deep into my own sulking and isolated myself, without realizing that the extent of my self hatred ended up affecting my friends too and they didn't deserve that. But I guess it's not easy to be a good friend when your mind is too busy creating a parallel reality where time doesn't pass and also trying to convince you to end your life.[/spoiler] Hopefully this time with the help of my therapist, my life might get better :3
ok enough venting on steam wtf what a loser sorry but this game is important to me, now here's an actual review: 

[b]pros: BEAUTIFUL artstyle, compelling story, lovely characters (some better than others...) fun gameplay (well I'm a rpg fan so I might be biased) 

cons: omocat didn't milk her beautiful artstyle in this platform by adding trading cards/points shop items, so I can't buy and wear an animated Kel avatar like god intended me to. That sucks... [/b]


[strike](p.s: btw a considerable part of the fandom is toxic as hell. if you love this game, interact with fans at your own risk)[/strike]

147958809.review:
You'll be scratching your head for about the first third of the game wondering what the hell is going on - but you'll also have this strong urge to continue because you're actually curious about what the hell is happening. Not many games manage to pull off this fine balance. The combat isn't amazing, the graphics are clearly made on RPG maker, and the game has a couple of annoying bugs. Yet none of that really matters. This game will take you on a wild ride exploring yours and Omori's psyche. 

Be warned though that aspects of this game are incredibly dark and as such this game might not be for everyone. I wouldn't classify it as a horror but it's a hell of a psychological thriller.

PS: If you're having the game flicker while playing in full screen, disable Windows Full Screen Optimisation in the properties of the EXE file.

I haven't felt this connection to a RPG in years. 
The story is captivating. I (sadly) lost many achievements because I was so captured with it that i just NEEDED to get to the ending. I don't want to give away too much, because is better to play and discover, if you are looking for your next addiction, this might be it. Perfect combination of cuteness, sillines and depression, big time depression.

Many people have compared this game to Undartale, and I can see why. The mechanics and the the style of the story are quite similar (both so serious and absurd at the same time). And just like Undertale, Omori demands hours of playtime and makes you want play it again and again. 

I will say, as a scary cat, I had to play some parts during the daytime, but the horror is mostly within the atmosphere and maybe one or two (small) jumpscares. Nothing harsh, but play consciously.

147716096.review:
The horse (Equus ferus caballus) is a domesticated, one-toed, hoofed mammal. It belongs to the taxonomic family Equidae and is one of two extant subspecies of Equus ferus. The horse has evolved over the past 45 to 55 million years from a small multi-toed creature, close to Eohippus, into the large, single-toed animal of today. Humans began domesticating horses around 4000 BCE, and their domestication is believed to have been widespread by 3000 BCE. Horses in the subspecies caballus are domesticated, although some domesticated populations live in the wild as feral horses. These feral populations are not true wild horses, which are horses that never have been domesticated. There is an extensive, specialized vocabulary used to describe equine-related concepts, covering everything from anatomy to life stages, size, colors, markings, breeds, locomotion, and behavior.

Horses are adapted to run, allowing them to quickly escape predators, and possess an excellent sense of balance and a strong fight-or-flight response. Related to this need to flee from predators in the wild is an unusual trait: horses are able to sleep both standing up and lying down, with younger horses tending to sleep significantly more than adults. Female horses, called mares, carry their young for approximately 11 months and a young horse, called a foal, can stand and run shortly following birth. Most domesticated horses begin training under a saddle or in a harness between the ages of two and four. They reach full adult development by age five, and have an average lifespan of between 25 and 30 years.

Horse breeds are loosely divided into three categories based on general temperament: spirited "hot bloods" with speed and endurance; "cold bloods", such as draft horses and some ponies, suitable for slow, heavy work; and "warmbloods", developed from crosses between hot bloods and cold bloods, often focusing on creating breeds for specific riding purposes, particularly in Europe. There are more than 300 breeds of horse in the world today, developed for many different uses.

Horses and humans interact in a wide variety of sport competitions and non-competitive recreational pursuits as well as in working activities such as police work, agriculture, entertainment, and therapy. Horses were historically used in warfare, from which a wide variety of riding and driving techniques developed, using many different styles of equipment and methods of control. Many products are derived from horses, including meat, milk, hide, hair, bone, and pharmaceuticals extracted from the urine of pregnant mares. Humans provide domesticated horses with food, water, and shelter as well as attention from specialists such as veterinarians and farriers.

147695888.review:
So, there's a lot... In every sense.

I mean, the game is quite long and it feels like it shouldn't be that way. And there's a lot to keep in mind, which is kinda hard since the game switches between two worlds, with every turn taking enough time to forget what you did before you switched. And also, there's a lot of emotions to deal with, a whole spectrum of them, starting with happy (also sad and angry if yk what I mean) moments, finishing with uncertainty and confusion about some of the characters' stories.

All these points are kinda controversial, I know, and I totally wouldn't recommend this game for everyone. The thing I liked the most was digging through the stories of characters, their motifs (are there any motifs for something you didn't mean to do?), feelings , thoughts and I could keep this list going. This game gave me space for thinking, which is why I liked it. It just feels good to do some thinking from time to time, you know. Like, would I act the same way? Would I feel the same? Why did it happen like that? What could it mean? Stuff like that. I also enjoyed finding little secrets (it implies backtracking, which I enjoyed too, it had its little details), thinking through battle tactics and hoarding. Plus, I don't mind some grind, so there's that.

Art and soundtrack are judged subjectively, but I liked those a lot, it's simple yet it fits so perfectly. I'm into this kind of aesthetic, so yeah, that counts too.

And I know the line of thought in my review is scattered all over the place, so as my thoughts about this game. I started playing it 3 times, 2 of them I quickly lost interest, the 3rd time I'm finally close to finishing it. At least I think so. Would've I lost a lot, if I hadn't played it? I don't think so. Would I recommend it? Yes, somewhat as a piece of culture, if I may say so. It's something that you should play and think through for yourself. The story was quite controversial for me, I don't agree on some things, I don't believe some things, but it made me think a lot. Give it a try, maybe you'll like it.

And here could be my staircase joke, but idk, just imagine there is one.

147652513.review:
No amount of preparing will be enough to be ready to play this game. This game will unveil truths and thoughts about yourself that you might've never even known existed, and you can never forget. There is no turning back after you play this game. 

By this point, I've played a fair share of games dealing with mental illnesses/psychological horror, but I don't think any game is able to grasp it as well as Omori. It steadily and subtly introduces new horrors to the player, but most of the time, not in a way that feels forced or "jumpscare-y".

This is probably the best game I've played in the past 5 years. The art style is one of the most creative and recognizable art style's I've seen (I'm also a bit of biased in the form of pixel art, so I understand if not everyone likes that). In addition, I don't think most of the horror/emotional parts of this game would hit so hard if it wasn't for the music. The entire soundtrack has a mix of action/happy/nostalgic/depressing songs, with some songs in particular managing to achieve multiple emotions at once (something I find quite rare in music). The gameplay, for the most part, is pretty standard for a turn-based RPG. Furthermore, I never really found it too difficult (I never got a game over in my first run). That being said, Omori has it's own unique elements that make fighting enemies a lot more fun and creative.

The theme and writing of this game is unlike anything I've seen before, but I want to leave this mostly spoiler free (and trust me this is way better when you know little about it going into it), so I wont be diving deep into that. [spoiler] I've only completed a few neutral endings so far - my opinion on this game might change after seeing those, who knows - but as for now, [/spoiler] I give this a 9/10.

Omori es, sin lugar a dudas, un juego que se destaca como una joya en el mundo de los juegos de rol (y mi videojuego favorito). Con una historia cautivadora que te atrapa desde el principio, es imposible no sentirse inmerso en cada uno de los mundos que te ofrece.

En cuanto a la calificación, no puedo evitar darle un ROTUNDO 10/10, si eres fanático de los juegos de rol y buscas un viaje emocional a través de un mundo encantador, este es sin duda un título del que no te podrás olvidar. 

Te amo Sunny.

147486518.review:
The gameplay is very simplistic and relies heavily on the plot, but the plot is just not enough to justify the length of the game. I was looking forward to the segments set in the real world and white space. But if that's what you're playing the game for, it just isn't worth playing the game. Very little time is spent in those segments, and they don't reveal much.  To enjoy the game you have to basically treat the story about the protagonist's trauma as an unimportant C-plot happening in the background.

You need to be thoroughly focused on what's happening in the otherworld, which is not much: You're searching for this character named Basil. You explore an area, sit through goofy Undertale-style comedy stalling antics, do some very easy RPG combat, and the characters say "welp, Basil's not here, let's go check the next area". That's the otherworld plot and you'll be spending 95% of the game doing that.

The otherworld plot tries to mimic Undertale, but the devs don't seem to understand what made Undertale work. Undertale antagonists have a personal reason why they're trying to stop the protagonist, and the touching moments involve the protagonist in some way. Omori antagonists are just random characters who show up to harass the protagonist for no reason in particular. I do some unimportant quest for a few hours, this character just suddenly attacks me, and then says "Yeah I have no idea where Basil is. Okay bye." Several grueling hours later I'm still looking for Basil, have gained no new information, and the antagonist maybe had a nice moment with their own friends that had nothing to do with the protagonist at all. This is just stalling the plot for nothing.

It isn't doing something subtextual, and while things in the otherworld are certainly modeled after the real world, they don't really symbolize anything. I.E., a place in the otherworld is named after a place in the real world, that's all. The otherworld segments are not saying anything deeper than that. The game has some interesting ideas with the emotion mechanics and follow-up attacks, but it's pretty basic, you don't have to be trying much at all.

As for the real-world story about the protagonist, it's more stalling. The prologue gives you almost nothing. After several grueling hours, the end of chapter 1 finally reveals some things about what's happening with the protagonist and his relationships to the other characters, but it features even more characters showing up to attack you for no reason and speaking but giving no info before leaving, just to pad the game time. While it does finally tell you something at that point, it's hard to even be invested in what's happening with Basil in the real world. The times you "save" him from the bullies... he was actually just harassing them in the park and they were yelling at him to leave them alone... then I guess to show that they're bad people, they attack you for no reason when you show up. And then after four more hours, the end of chapter 2 gives you literally nothing - it just repeats the same plot points it showed you after chapter 1. No new information has been introduced, and it totally skips whitespace in a cutscene. Four hours of gameplay and nothing about the plot has changed whatsoever. 

The game is basically just wasting your time for nothing. The old "stall the journey as long as possible to make the destination feel more impactful than it really is" trick. I definitely can't recommend it to anyone. If it has some compelling story or message to tell, well that's too bad the author chose to stall so much for such superficial reasons, because I won't be finishing it.

147110448.review: Oh wow, what an experience. The game's story is truly something else, I'm speechless. The narrative had a lot of twist and turns and fooled me multiple times. Although i recommend this game for its narrative, the game play loop gets really stale after a while, especially in the middle of the game. In the dream world, the story is all over the place and dialogue felt like it was written by a middle schooler, which might be what they were going for, but i just found myself dragging through story and characters i just didn't care about, like the shark guy and the pink princess. The real world segment was incredibly enjoyable though, and i found the contrast between the dream world and the real world really appealing. The story touches on some dark topics like depression, regret, fear and self hatred and the game managed to pull it together really well. Overall 9/10, the story is incredible, although the repetitive gameplay loop stops the game from being a 10/10 in my opinion.

146901661.review:
Heartbreaking and beautiful.

EDIT:  Okay, now that I have sufficient time and distance from finishing the game for the first time, I can offer a more expanded opinion.

I left this game feeling hollowed out and as though I will never play it again. This is because I got what is widely considered the Good Ending, and it broke my heart. But don't mistake me: This game is a masterpiece.

What tons of modern media attempts (and fails) to convey, Omori manages. Through music, color application, and player choices, Omori so clearly expresses what it's like to lose oneself. Often it does this with bright pastels, wacky characters, and dreamworld logic. You find yourself thinking, "This is so cute! What is that?" Charmed by the absurdity, the painful parts are *more* painful. The terrifying parts? Anxiety-inducing. I left this game sympathizing with characters I never thought I'd sympathize with, for actions I still don't completely understand, even though the outcome of those actions was genuinely distressing for me, the player.

Omori wrestles with huge emotions, and it does it through a pixelated, nostalgic lens. I walked in without exposure to any of the spoilers, and I was completely unprepared for the way it crushed my heart in my chest.

This game is psychological horror at its best. The feelings this game made me feel are feelings that i dont think any other game will make me feel. Its beautiful yet sad i love it so much. 100% recommend this game if u like psychological horror and rpg games. This game was just so good i could write a whole essay about what i felt when playing this game but im lazy so yeah play this game.

146707905.review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER BEFORE I START! [/h1] 
[u] I just wanted to say that I am not a game critic. Everything that I'm about to say is entirely my opinion. [/u]


I am not a big fan of RPGs. I find turn-based combat to be tedious and annoying, because it feels like you barely have any control over what's happening. I was hesitant to play this game at first, but my friend convinced me into playing it somehow. I was hoping that maybe, just maybe, this game would be different. And after about 20 hours of playing the game, I can safely say, without a doubt, that Omori is not a good game. It is almost exactly like I thought it would be. It would be harsh of me to say that it's bad, but it does have a few problems that weigh it down. This might seem very petty, but I'll get back to this later. For now, I want to talk about the things I like about the game, because it does offer some neat stuff.



Pros: 

I want to start off by getting the obvious out of the way. The story (From what I've played) is good. Most of the characters, even though they are quite simple, are pretty like-able. I've never really felt emotional during the game however. though I guess that's not something I should be saying since I'm a heartless bastard, and I barely get emotional towards anything. I really don't have any gripes with the story that I can think of [spoiler] although I find it kinda weird that the game lets you choose your own name later on, when his "Canonical" (which is a word that I hate) is Sunny. It gets a little weird later on when the characters say something like "Your sister passed away, Poo" during what's supposed to be emotional moments. Again, this is nit-picky, and also kinda your own choice, so I won't count this as a negative. [/spoiler] Oh yeah there is one problem that I have with the story, but we'll get there later on, as it sort of ties into something else I will be talking about later in the review. But over-all, I really can't say that the story is bad. Maybe the best part of the game, though to be fair, I'm only about halfway through. 

The artstyle and animations are very good and well-made. Especially the hand-drawn stuff. It almost makes me wish that the entire game was hand-drawn and that there wasn't any pixel-art. [spoiler] Except for the clay monsters, they're pretty cool and stand out since they are made from clay. [/spoiler]

The music is decent, though probably nothing I'd listen to in my free time.

The gameplay is both part of the good and the bad of the game. For now, let's talk about what's good about the gameplay: The side-quests are pretty fun. Nothing ground-breaking, and they don't give you much for doing them, but they're service-able. Most of the time they're just fetch-quests, but the places are usually pretty fun to explore. Another thing I'd like to mention is the combat. Now, even as someone who isn't a big fan of turn-based combat, Omori has some pretty cool ideas. It's pretty interesting and it has a few things going for it. There are 3 emotions; [spoiler] (technically 4) [/spoiler] Anger, happiness and sadness. [spoiler] there's also fear, which is a pretty interesting addition. It adds both to the gameplay and story, but mostly the story. Fear is the worst out of all the emotions, making you practically useless. It's also the rarest out of all the emotions, because none of your team-mates have any skills to make you afraid. [/spoiler] The combat is basically a more complicated version of rock-paper-scissors, with RPG turn-based combat fused together with it. Anger deals more damage to sadness, happiness deals more damage to anger, and sadness deals more damage to happiness. There's also neutral, which is basically in between it all. Everyone in your group have different skills, Omori having the ability to make people sad, Aubrey having the ability to make people happy, Kel having the ability to make people angry, and Hero, who... Well... He just cooks. There's a bit more to the combat than that, but these are just the basics. It can be pretty fun, however, there are at least two problems with the combat that ruin it all.



Cons:

[spoiler] first off, let's talk about my one gripe with the story: spoiler At one point in the game, you're in the real world, and Kel knocks on the door. You get the option to either open the door, or to not answer. Depending on which answer you choose, you get one out of two routes. If you choose to not answer the door, you apparently get a more gameplay-focused route. If you do choose to open the door, you get a more story-focused route. This is fine on paper, but in execution, it's not handled well. You see, this choice changes the story, meaning that this is a very big decision. Luckily, I happened to know about this, due to my friend telling me. But still. There should be at least SOME indication that this choice will cause big changes to the story. I get that you can just reload to your last save or whatever, but what if you haven't saved in a while? Or you didn't think this would change much, so you decide to overwrite your last save? What's worse is that this is basically the ONE choice in the ENTIRE GAME that matters this much. So you have basically no reason to think that this will change the story much. I think they could have handled this a bit better. [/spoiler]

The difficulty: Oh my god is the difficulty balance absolutely horrible. After the first hour or so, the game throws you right in, expecting you to understand everything, because the game wants you to do a bunch of endless grinding, when the combat isn't even that fun. I may like some of the ideas the combat has, but it's not fun enough for you to fight a million enemies just so that you can beat the next boss. The game has an identity crisis. It tries to have a compelling story, and at the same time be a pokémon game or something. People might say something along the lines of "Well, the game isn't supposed to have great gameplay, it focuses more on story", except that isn't even fucking true, because the game DOES focus on gameplay. It wants you to do a bunch of endless stupid fucking grinding, because if you don't do a bunch of endless stupid fucking grinding, you can't even BEAT THE STUPID FUCKING BOSSES AND MAKE ANY PROGRESS, NO MATTER WHAT ROUTE YOU CHOOSE! It's dumb. It's really dumb. But I'm not done yet. Because you know what? I could forgive the last two things I just pointed out, if it wasn't for one more flaw, which we'll talk about right now. The flaw that ruins the entire flow of the combat.

The one flaw that ruins the entire flow of the combat:
You see, during combat, the enemy can sometimes attack you in the middle of your turn. Now, at first, you might not think much of it, but when you really think about it, this addition doesn't make sense or work at all. And trust me, it gets VERY annoying later in the game. You might be thinking "What's wrong with this? It adds more challenge to the combat. Isn't that a good thing?" and you might be right for thinking that. But the truth is, doesn't it kinda ruin the point of turn-based combat? Isn't the point of turn-based combat for there to be... You know... TURNS!? For you to plan your next move based on the enemy's attacks? Here, you can't even do that, because the enemy is so unpredictable. It ends up with the enemy killing someone part of your team, and then making you waste a healing item, because yes, if you were planning on using a healing item on someone with low health and they die during a turn, you will waste the healing item, and it will instead go to Omori. Who the hell thought this was a good idea? I completely disagree with this addition to the turn-based combat.

Over-all, I'm giving Omori a 6/10. If you're really into turn-based combat, or you wanna support the devs, then maybe I'd recommend. Otherwise, you're better off watching a 5 hour long youtube analysis.

146677194.review:
Worth the money.
1) Story-focused RPG - less emphasis on combat and more on exploring the world and interacting with its characters, but still has a combat system that feels nice to use (in my opinion).
2) Godly soundtrack. Not every song will make you get up off your chair and start dancing, but they all have a place. If a song comes off as particularly grating or annoying to you, it's probably intentional.
3) Interesting and engaging story. Has a compelling narrative that still leaves the player room to fill in the blanks with their own imagination. Works well with the 'find-it-yourself' manner of uncovering the story in the first place.
4) Pleasant art style that is expertly manipulated to fit vastly different situations.
Be aware before purchasing the game for yourself or others that it contains references to and/or depictions of: self-harm, gore, suicide, mental illness, and embarassing childhood friends that you can't seem to get to leave you alone.
This is now one of my favorite games of all time. If what you've read sounds appealing, and you're alright with the game's content, I highly recommend it.

146675158.review:
The creator is creepy and weird, so don't support them if you can help it. The game, on the other hand, is entirely lovely. Everything about OMORI is beautiful. It takes you through a tragic story from the view of a traumatized young boy, Sunny, who lost his older sister, Mari. Multiple endings, all different from each other.

Trigger warnings for depression, suicide, self-harm, hanging, disturbing imagery, animal abuse, flashing lights, etc. Lots of things to be wary of with OMORI.

146668350.review:
If you haven't played the game, don't read this whole review. Please and thank you. But if you're looking for an opinion on the game itself, I recommend that you play it.
I haven't 100%'d it yet, but I'm gonna finally stop waiting to write this review. I already did everything there is to do on the console release and I certainly plan to 100% this version of the game as well.
This is one of the greatest games ever made. Genuinely, the only story in any video game to genuinely bring me to tears. It is absolutely beautiful and it's depictions of trauma and grief are absolutely incredible, as you get to see more than 1 side of both. You get to understand how all the characters grieve for their lost friend and you get to see the differences between how SUNNY and BASIL handled their traumatic experience. The only thing I can even slightly complain about is the gameplay, which is boring and repetitive once you've figured it out. I highly recommend installing mods to increase the difficulty/add more diversity in how you play the game.
100/10. Amazing game. If only another game could come even close to it. I'll miss this game forever.

Overall a Perfect Game!

146443745.review:
I should preface by saying that I was seriously considering writing this review before I even finished the game, being how much it changed me. However, it made sense waiting until I had gone through everything to give my thoughts. If I could describe Omori, to new players, in one sentence it would be this: “Get ready.” I was aware that this game had many depressed after playing it, and that made me curious. Despite claiming that it hurt them, they still deeply recommended it. I agree with their logic. Omori gives a remarkable projection to the sorrows of life, from the lens of innocence and vulnerability. It’s not one that is easy, but it’s one that is sincere. This game had me both deeply terrified and sad, but all at the same time, more compelled to continue. Not many have this capability. So, despite whatever pain you might feel from playing this game, I still believe that you will have found the journey worth it.

My life will never quite be the same.

146380637.review:
A lovely RPG about getting over trauma
[h2]Rating: 5/5[/h2]
[h3]Music: 5/5[/h3]

[h3]Gameplay: 4/5[/h3]
- Fun & deep turn-based combat
- Exploration through an open world that is pretty much always rewarding
- Has surprises on how different systems can be recontextualized

[h3]Graphics: 5/5[/h3]
(idk how they could be any better)

[h3]Story: 6/5[/h3]
- Interesting & lovable characters
- [b]I have never felt emotions from any media as strong as I have felt from this game[/b]
- Funny
(Not really spoilers, but whatever)
- [spoiler]Multiple layers to everything that kinda like interweave and interact with each other in crazy ways that you don't expect yet make sense[/spoiler] 
- [spoiler]Multiple endings[/spoiler] 
- [spoiler]Ends up being also realistic to what its trying to portray[/spoiler] [spoiler](PTSD)[/spoiler] 
- Its just great

[h3]Length/Price[/h3]
- >30 hours of content for me (I did like 2/3 the side quests)
- I would think it would have been worth if it were 40 or even 50 bucks

[h3]Criticisms:[/h3]
- Occasionally it wants you to do a specific thing, but (very rarely and for really not that long) your not sure & you end up going in circles or doing backtracking
- Basic movement is a little bit boring, but doesn't matter most of the time and is only a problem because of above
- Saving only happens a certain locations, not when you close the game. There are plenty check points in most places, but can be a tinge of annoyance
- I am a person who has a real hard time understanding extended metaphors & this game has a lot of them & does a much better job than 90% of other things with them. However the last couple hours of the game get a little more 'abstract' (not a bad thing & necessary for what it is trying todo) and I was only able to partly (mostly) follow along. If your a normal person then you should have no issue
- This game sucked my life away and from the point I started to the point I finished, all I could think about was this game (I will probably continue to for a couple days into the future too)

That is literally all of my criticisms. Everything else is perfect. And each item is really small, they are only keeping the game from a 6/5.

All in all, 5/5 > 2/5 so I recommend it

146127212.review:
[h3]Reseña sin spoilers[/h3]
De alguna manera pude ignorar este juego durante 3 años, 0 spoilers. Definitivamente así se deberían jugar todos los juegos: a ciegas. Sólo juégalo sin ver ni oír absolutamente nada previamente.

[h3]Reseña con spoilers[/h3]

OMORI te rompe la cabeza con su excelente historia, personajes vivos, música, efectos de sonido, ambientación, diálogos, arte única (la mezcla de pixel art con dibujo a mano e incluso fotografía real), etc. La variedad de escenarios es brutal, las zonas están muy bien delimitadas, cada una con sus respectivas paletas de colores, leitmotivs y justificaciones distintas.

En un principio, el combate me pareció flojo e incluso injusto, pero a medida que lo iba entendiendo más y más, vi que realmente está bien trabajado, aunque a veces se vuelva un poco tedioso con los enemigos que hay esparcidos en las zonas (que, por cierto, se agradece la ausencia de encuentros aleatorios). Definitivamente, donde más relucen las mecánicas como los sentimientos es con los jefes. La variedad de ataques que hay por cada personaje evita que las batallas sean sólo spammear un botón, sino que te hace pensar en alguna estrategia y así cada personaje toma un rol.

En cuanto a la historia, es lo que más destaca de este juego. Sabes que hay algo que está muy mal, el juego te confunde a propósito y luego empiezas a conectar todas las piezas. Paulatinamente, se te va desvelando la historia a un ritmo adecuado. Es cierto que algunas zonas se sentían de relleno (en especial la parte de Humphrey o la mazmorra de Sweetheart), pero se puede justificar con lo que se supone que es Omori para Sunny. La simbología que maneja OMORI es excepcional, todas las zonas tienen su porqué, su significado; las metáforas y la manipulación de las acciones del jugador están muy bien llevadas.

A pesar de que no me ha ocurrido ni de cerca lo mismo que en el juego, puedo llegar a comprender fácilmente lo que se siente el sufrir en soledad y hasta puedo empatizar con algunos momentos clave. Este juego da miedo por lo absurdamente crudo que es, te hace consciente de que en cualquier momento tu vida puede cambiar por completo, consecuencia de cualquier mínima acción. Nunca se está preparado para la impredecibilidad de la existencia misma y la consciencia es el peor enemigo de la sanidad mental.

OMORI plasma la natural incapacidad humana de engañarse a sí mismo al ir deteriorando progresivamente la estabilidad mental de alguien que intenta vivir una realidad autosaboteada.

146098563.review:
Some spoilers, sorry. This is one of the best games I've played, and already I can tell it will be the closest to my heart. Where do I even begin? The headspace portions of the game are absolutely wonderful, they're full of vibrant locations and striking scenery. It all looks so cute. Whenever I played through them, I had a big smile on my face and that is RARE. It has a dreamlike and childish quality in the best sense possible, I'm not exaggerating at all when I say that playing this game made me feel like a kid again. Maybe a little too much, actually, since I actually got a bit depressed from reminiscing :,) It's sense of humor was amazing, I don't think I can count how many times I chuckled from it's situational comedy or silliness. The portions in Faraway town are completely different, but in a good way. It has a more grounded tone and things are taken more seriously in these portions. Not to say it's all moody or devoid of humor, but it's just different. And they're absolutely perfect too. Seeing all of these characters interact was amazing, and seeing them work through their problems was even better. I actually caught myself wanting to go back to these portions whenever I started a headspace portion, though those thoughts were quickly silenced by how amazing they were, lol. And that's the thing, every single portion is absolutely lovely and perfect. One aspect is the clear winner though, and that's the psychological horror aspect of the game. It crops up whenever you least expect it, taking you by surprise. They never last too long throughout the game, just being as long as they need to. They're sprinkled throughout the game, up until the ending, where the horror finally takes front and center. And while this game may be silly and fun at times, what it really is in it's core is about trauma, and how the characters react to and deal with it. Loss is a central theme in this game, it hangs over the entirety of the real world sections, and it warps and distorts the black space section. The aesthetics of it all really take it up, looking like something a traumatized child would imagine. And that's because it is. The game confronts its protagonist for his sins, and every second of it is a horrific portrayal of trauma and depression. (MAJOR SPOILERS)


 Some visuals really stick out, as really, really, horrifying, like the image of Mari's lifeless body hanging from the tree. It really picks Sunny's brain and delves into all of his trauma due to Mari's death. But once you get through it all, you're met with this powerful, beautiful part where Sunny remembers his most treasured memories and decides to meet with the truth, and rises above his trauma. The final boss fight is so empowering that you almost get choked up, and the scene where Sunny and Mari finally get to do their duet and perform after never getting the chance to almost. made me bawl my eyes out. I don't ever cry when consuming media, but this is the closest i've ever gotten to it, I wish I could have to. be honest and let out all that emotion because that performance is the most emotional scene I have ever seen in a game. At the end of it all, Sunny learns to keep moving forward, and to forgive himself and accept the truth. It's an empowering and emotional ending to a game that i'll come to cherish. Omori is a game with no counterpart. I have no reservations calling it one of the greatest games of all time.

146085104.review: Omori is an intriguing and satisfying dive into a young boy's mind as he reunites with childhood friends whilst battling personal demons. The game play at first comes across like a typical 2013 rpg maker game but the level of detail and exploration available grant it much more praise. The combat is refreshing with an emotion system that affects the stats of your party along with enemies and there is a  follow-up system used during combat so the turn based mechanics have a bit more interaction. The graphics are simple and appealing to the eye, cute and at times disturbing. What I appreciate most visually are the hand drawn cut scenes and images you encounter throughout the story, as well as hidden easter eggs. Sound design is spot on for the story and game play, it can go from something reminiscent to 90s SNES rpg battle music to foreboding and uncomfortable tones and it all fits well. The story took me by surprise, themes of isolation, childhood trauma and suppressed thoughts are commonplace and done tastefully and creatively but there was much more I did not expect. As I carried on playing I would lose track of time, eager to see what would happen next as I became quite invested in the characters. Not many games have a story that keeps me wanting more, like a book I can't put down, but Omori is certainly near the top of the list. I would implore anyone that enjoys dark psychological stories and rpgs to give this game a shot.

146079100.review:
Perhaps my favorite game, and I don't say that lightly. This game was given to me by a friend of mine a couple of years ago, and I cannot thank him enough for it. I have never bothered doing reviews much at all but I wanted to make an exception with this one. 

This game changed the way I look at my life, The ending hit me right in the heart and is probably the only game to really do so. If there was a game I would say is truly a masterpiece, I would say this one. I can't say that for other games that I have played, as good as a lot of them are. 

The first couple hours in this game gave me a feeling deep down that there is something special about it and I instantly liked it from then on, from the visuals to the great OST. (Trying to be spoiler free) 

Those that have had feelings or thoughts similar to what the game depicts will probably find something relatable to it. Like I did. And I can say it really helped a lot in a way.

Thank you OMOCAT and everyone else that worked on this game. And thank you my friend, for getting me this game. It really is a true work of art. Highly recommended you play this.

-A very satisfied Steam User

146075000.review:
I'm going to start by saying that I know there are people who get a lot out of this game, and I do not want to take that from them. If you have played the game, and you like it for the emotional support it gave you, then please do not read the rest of this because it will just upset you.

The gameplay is uninspired and not rewarding, however, no one talks about this game in that regard as it is the story of Omori that seems to really hook others. If you are looking for RPG maker games with an interesting combat system alone, look elsewhere.

I'm going to try to voice what didn't work for me about Omori's story with minimal spoilers:

Fans of Omori's story often attribute the story to being a deep dive into depression and struggles with self harm. However, the ending of the game opts to instead discard any notion of this. This game's story is better understood through the lens of selfishness and guilt. A selfishness that a keen player will notice does not dissipate even once the game comes to a close. Sunny (the main character) is seen in the eyes of the narrative as a victim when he provides nothing for his friends and asks for everything in return. It is laughable to believe the story when it says that group of kids were friends as there is absolutely no reason for Sunny to be anything more than tolerated by them. 

Without detail, but still some might consider this a spoiler, the story ends with a conclusion that sees Sunny persuaded to do the right thing about his past actions not because of a moral obligation or duty to a higher virtue, but is instead convinced by the thought that his friends will certainly forgive him. His actions are a poor model for others, and the fact that the creator seems to endorse the mindset and behavior of Sunny is worrying and appalling. 

This game could retain large sweeps of its story and be great if the message wasn't so twisted by a need to make this poor behavior seem noble or correct. I played through Omori with the hope that I could see what others were seeing in this game. I absolutely adore stories that speak on dark themes or have complicated characters, but this story is not thought out and displays a dangerous selfishness without labeling it as such. I believe that most people who enjoy the game's story are good people, and most likely, they just ignore or have written off where this story has failed them as players. The aesthetic of Omori helps in enthralling some players to overlook these things, but if you are someone who has yet to play this game, I am telling you that it is not worth your time. If you decide to play it anyway, and you like it, then great, don't let anyone take that away from you, but please at least take the time to consider what the story might really be saying and how you inform or respond to it.

146015744.review: Omori takes a familiar RPG format and creates something entirely new out of it. The battle mechanics are engaging, the boss battles are exciting, and the music is fantastic. Just like with Toby Fox's Undertale, Omori feels like you bought an album that came with a game along with it as a bonus. On top of all that, the story is full of mystery and intrigue that only give you more questions the farther you get into it.
